greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Fermi-Dirac factorization prime shift towards larger terms: a(n) = A052330(2*A052331(n)).
comment: With n having a unique factorization as A050376(i) * A050376(j) * ... * A050376(k), with i, j, ..., k all distinct, a(n) = A050376(1+i) * A050376(1+j) * ... * A050376(1+k).
Multiplicative because for coprime m and n the Fermi-Dirac factorizations of m and n are disjoint and their union is the Fermi-Dirac factorization of m * n. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Aug 02 2018
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..32768
program: i = 0; for(n=1,oo,if(ispow2(isprimepower(n)), i++; v050376[i] = n); if(i == up_to_e,break));

A052331(n) = { my(s=0,e); while(n > 1, fordiv(n, d, if(((n/d)>1)&&ispow2(isprimepower(n/d)), e = vecsearch(v050376, n/d); if(!e, print("v050376 too short!"); return(1/0)); s += 2^(e-1); n = d; break))); (s); };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 12 2018
